where_to_read: Leaves of grass are all up in my stuff

reviews.review_text: Capote's writing is captivating.  Although he is best known for In Cold Blood, I prefer these earlier stories.  Breakfast at Tiffany's  was a good movie but the original story by Truman Capote is captivating in another way, delving into a broader range of characters and life in the New York of the late 50s.Also notable in this collection is A Christmas Memory, one of my favorite Christmas stories. It is beautifully written about interesting people.  Capote at his best.
Meh.  I didn't like one person in the book, so I didn't enjoy it at all.
I chose my rating as having only ever seen the movie I decided to read the book...It is very powerful and evokes a tale as old as time.
Truman Capote fantastic as always. Poetry as prose. Three separate stories. Capote, like Ray Bradbury, can enchant the mundane with magical fire.

I will not go into a summary of the book as has been done very adequately in previous reviews.  I purchased the audio version of this book because I’m a fan of borh Mr. Hall and Capote.  I’ve seen the movie as well as having read the book (MANY years ago).  However, hearing the book read was a bit of a revelation.  The movie was somewhat different because back in the 60s, when it was made “required” several changes according to studio heads.  All of the gay references were removed.  If I’m not mistaken, Paul was even gay in the book. In any event, the time period in which the book is set is the 40s so the reader  is.saddled with some racial perjoratives.  Small criticism since those were quite “appropriate” for the time period.  As indicated above, I was most impressed with MCH’s narration.  The voices he used for different characters were excellent.  I honestly thought they had a female narrating Holly’s voice for about the first quarter of the book.  Is there anything MCH can’t do?  I won’t explain here why I gave it four stars instead of five as that might be considered a spoiler.Recommended.

I didn’t even realize the book even ended and continued to read the next short story thinking it had some connection and of course it didn’t. Disappointing. Had to google some descriptions in the book from the lighting of a cigarette part lol that was the first time hearing this “saying” why are there such good reviews on this??
In rereading this book it makes me sad to realize he’s gone and no longer producing quiet masterpieces like this.

With the possible exception of the Herbert Clutter family of IN COLD BLOOD, Miss Holiday Golightly, "Traveling," has to be Truman Capote's best-known figure.  Those who have seen the movie with Audrey Hepburn may be surprised to read Capote's World War II-set novella and learn that "Holly" was more of a demimondaine -- and a bit of a racist -- compared to the beguiling movie.  Still, it's captivating reading.  Perhaps better yet, this volume includes Capote's etheral first novel, OTHER VOICES OTHER ROOMS, written in a style of literary symbolism that captures so well the changes a young orphan goes through when he leaves home, connects with distant relatives in a distant location, and realizes his sexuality.  These two stories are so rich and enjoyable that a hardcover is really the way to go for repeat readings.

Breakfast at Tiffany's -  Maybe I'm spoiled by the movie, or maybe I just don't like Capote? Either way I wasn't overly charmed with the book. Truly, I prefer protagonists I like, and Holly isn't terribly likeable...  It's a classic, probably deservedly so, but it's not my cup of tea. 2 stars.House of Flowers -  I actually really enjoyed this one.  The descriptions, the plot, characters, and just the general flow was lovely to read. I didn't like the last sentence one bit but I can overlook that. 5 starsDiamond Guitar - I have no strong opinion on this story. Nice enough, but quite short. 3 starsA Christmas Memory - 4 stars
Such a beautifully written story! It is different from the movie and more subversive.Nice to have included some other lovely stories, especially "A Christmas Memory".

summary: In this seductive, wistful masterpiece, Truman Capote created a woman whose name has entered the American idiom and whose style is a part of the literary landscape. Holly Golightly knows that nothing bad can ever happen to you at Tiffany's; her poignancy, wit, and naïveté continue to charm.
story_arc: Opens with good fortunes, but doomed to fail
